ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned about lift, drag, circulation, and airfoil design. Showed basic theory of aerodynamics and applications of fluid dynamics. Lots of open end engineering problem solving
I think I learned a bit about numerically solving some simple supersonic problems. Other than that I am not really sure.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strength was teacher. He was very accessible and clearly very much cared about learning. However the information was extremely unorganized. Students struggled through problem sets and we could barely get through any problem without hearing results directly from the teacher

I think most of the issues come down to the choice of professor for this course. But setting him aside for a minute: There needs to be more real-world connection. This is a mechanical engineering elective, not a theory course. We spent long enough learning about math that I think I forgot some of the fluid mechanics I learned in junior year.
It starts out very theoretical, but it becomes more and more practical and most things come together over time.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
De la Mora is a very unorganized teacher but I would recommend this course. The material is so interesting. Never do you get a cooler application of a very hard subject than getting to use your boring fluid knowledge to apply it to planes.

The problem sets are not long but very difficult. Luckily there are problem sessions where de la Mora walks you through challenging problems.

Go in with comfortable math knowledge and ability to apply fluids otherwise it will be very hard

No. It's only an elective, you can afford to choose something else. Beth Bennett's classes may be harder and require more work, but you will be much more motivated to work in them because she is an excellent teacher and you'll know what's going on. This one was a real struggle, probably the worst class I've taken in college.
If you're interested in understand why plane wings are shaped the way that they are from a math perspective (think back to Fluids) then yes.
